stream_context.summary: On his birthday, Kaze worked on Course 14. He focused on creating a new 'paper spring' object, struggling with its 3D model before programming and refining its physics to be more player-friendly. He also had a major breakthrough in level design, deciding to use a 'schizophrenic' design philosophy and redesigning a boring fetch quest to be an interactive puzzle using a crayon mechanic.

development_findings.summary: A key design breakthrough occurred when the team decided the crayon should be a tool to draw elements like bridges or platforms into existence, solving a fetch-quest design problem.
development_findings.quote: What if you use the crayon to draw something on the floor to make progress? Oh, now we are going somewhere.

development_findings.summary: Kaze experimented with applying texture filtering to the game but ultimately rejected it, preferring the sharper, unfiltered look for the HUD and world textures.

After finding that realistic physics made the new paper spring object too 'jelly' and hard to use, Kaze intentionally altered the code to make its behavior less realistic but more predictable and fun for platforming.
development_findings.quote: This is less realistic. But it should work. Just be more predictable for the player. Yeah, that does feel very predictable now.

development_findings.summary: Kaze struggled significantly with modeling the 3D geometry of a folded paper spring, finding it deceptively complex before moving on to coding its behavior.
Kaze is focused on refactoring code to create general-purpose functions (e.g., for sliding physics) that can be applied to multiple objects, improving code efficiency.
development_findings.quote: I want to work on making more general purpose functions for a lot of these objects. Because like the way I program the sliding of the crane now, I made it like one general purpose function that controls all the sliding for all objects at once.

development_findings.summary: A new mechanic was implemented where Luigi can find a lost crayon and use it to draw a star, which then becomes collectible. An idea was noted to make the crayon turn blue after use.
Kaze plans to implement a decal overlay system to show effects like oil or dirt on Mario's character model without making permanent changes.
The game's difficulty is being consciously managed to be accessible to beginners, with optional, self-imposed challenges providing difficulty for advanced players.
development_findings.quote: I don't think difficulty is essential to having fun in this game. But it does add some spice to it.

development_findings.summary: Kaze identified a platforming challenge involving a long jump to a spring as potentially too difficult and requiring a redesign to be less punishing.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes Nintendo's legal actions are based on calculated business decisions, not emotional reactions to jokes or 'taunts' from the fan community.
context_findings.quote: Nintendo is not one meathead that's getting upset if you look at them the wrong way. They are a big company making calculated decisions. They're not going to make a decision based on just one stupid joke tweet.

context_findings.summary: After re-evaluating Hazy Maze Cave, Kaze developed a new design philosophy focused on creating memorable experiences by combining seemingly random, disconnected elements in a level.
context_findings.quote: I realized you kind of need to just do random shit. You kind of just need to be schizophrenic and make connections that don't actually exist in your levels to maximize on that concept.

context_findings.summary: Kaze views extreme difficulty as an accessibility barrier that can prevent parts of the audience from playing. He distinguishes between challenging trial-and-error (like Dark Souls) and true difficulty that makes a game physically impossible for some players.
context_findings.quote: Someone once told me that games being difficult is like an accessibility issue. And I can kind of see that. ...for me true difficulty means that it's actually like some people can't play your game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze defines freedom in game design as the player's ability to experiment with movement and actions without being punished, which he feels is a core strength of Mario 64's engine.
context_findings.quote: Freedom is the ability to do things without a penalty basically.

context_findings.summary: Kaze ironically brainstormed marketing an original game by creating a persona of a creator who is constantly about to be 'canceled' by 'the woke left' for copyright infringement.
The stream took place on Kaze's birthday.

biobak.summary: Kaze showed Biobak the new crayon mechanic where Luigi can draw a star to collect it, seeking his feedback.
Kaze attributes the idea of adopting a 'right-wing grifter' persona for marketing to a suggestion from Biobak.
biobak.quote: If you're going with the Vogue left is trying to cancel me, Angle Bioware, maybe I should write a book.

zeina.summary: Zeina's presence is noted as supportive and personal; she was in the chat, bought Kaze a birthday cake, and made him chocolate milk.

key_stories.title: From Realistic to Fun: The Paper Spring Physics
key_stories.summary: Kaze programmed a new paper spring object, but its realistic physics made it too difficult to use. He deliberately altered the physics to be less realistic but more predictable, prioritizing a better player experience over simulation.
key_stories.challenge: The initial implementation of the paper spring used realistic physics, which made it feel too 'jelly' and unpredictable, making platforming difficult and frustrating for the player.
key_stories.process: Kaze first implemented the spring with realistic physics. After testing, he identified the 'jelly' feel as a problem. He then adjusted the physics parameters, reducing the oscillation and making the spring settle quickly after Mario lands on it, creating a more stable and usable platforming element.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze created a spring that behaves predictably and is fun to use. It compresses and expands in a way that gives the player clear control over their jump, prioritizing gameplay feel over physical accuracy.
key_stories.key_quote: This is less realistic. But it should work. Just be more predictable for the player. Yeah, that's perfectly realistic. This is typically how springs work in real life.

key_stories.title: Redesigning the Crayon Fetch Quest
key_stories.summary: A simple fetch quest to retrieve a crayon was redesigned into a more engaging puzzle. Instead of just carrying it back, the player will now use the crayon to draw objects into the world to create a path, making the objective and the tool one and the same.
key_stories.challenge: A planned quest to retrieve a lost crayon for Luigi felt like a boring fetch quest, requiring the player to simply walk to a location, pick up the crayon, and walk back.
key_stories.process: Kaze expressed dissatisfaction with the 'journey' of the crayon quest. He considered adding enemies or breakable blocks but found those ideas uninspired. The breakthrough came from the idea of making the crayon itself the solution, allowing the player to draw elements into the level to create their own path back.
key_stories.outcome: The crayon is now envisioned as a gameplay tool. The return journey will be a challenge where the player must use the crayon to draw platforms, bridges, or other objects to overcome obstacles, transforming a simple fetch quest into an interactive puzzle.
key_stories.key_quote: What if you use the crayon to draw something on the floor to make progress? Oh, now we are going somewhere.

key_stories.title: The 'Schizophrenic' Design Philosophy Revelation
key_stories.summary: Inspired by a re-evaluation of Hazy Maze Cave from the original SM64, Kaze decided to adopt a 'schizophrenic' level design philosophy. This involves intentionally combining random, logically disconnected elements to make levels more surprising and memorable.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze felt his level design could be more creative and memorable, but wasn't sure what principle to follow.
key_stories.process: While rating the levels of the original Super Mario 64, Kaze had a revelation about Hazy Maze Cave. He realized its strength and memorability came from the bizarre, illogical combination of elements like a toxic maze, rolling boulders, and a sea monster (Dory) in a metal pool. This inspired him to embrace randomness as a core design tenet.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze adopted a new design philosophy he calls 'schizophrenic design'. He now plans to intentionally place disparate and seemingly random elements together in levels to create surprising and memorable experiences for the player.
key_stories.key_quote: I realized you kind of need to just do random shit. You kind of just need to be schizophrenic and make connections that don't actually exist in your levels to maximize on that concept.
